About Me

Let me tell you a few things...

BIO

David Bauer is a devoted and dedicated husband, father, programmer, electrician, and musician.  Life has taken him in many unexpected directions, but he has kept a consistent attitude of professionalism and perseverance.  Relentless, passionate pursuit of knowledge in every area of his life has led to success throughout his career.

  -  

GE Lighting, a Savant company

Embedded SW QA Test Engineer / Electrician / Programmer.languages.push("C++", "JavaScript", "HTML", "CSS", "PLC", "Python", "Go");

Yes, HTML, CSS, and PLC programming (specifically Logicmaster and Proficy Machine Edition) are not considered to beprogra mming languages, but there you go...

In addition to maintaing the Access Controls system and all things electrical at GE Lighting's 97-acre NELA Park campus, I was introduced to embedded C++ and 3D printing.  I have experience with SolidWorks, but have become proficient with Autodesk's 123D Design and Fusion 360 products.   My PLC programming skills were fine-tuned with projects like building an entrance gate controller and animating our world-famous Christmas display!

Programming the PLC's for the display eventually led me to the amazing world of microcontrollers.  I immersed myself into embedded C++ development, learning everything I could about this new found world.  And as the programming bug worked its way through my system, web development became my next passion.

After an intense Coding Bootcamp at CWRU, I received a certificate in Full Stack Web Development.  Soon afterward, an opportunity became available on the Connected Home Team, putting my electrical, electronics and programming skills to the test.  My favorite project was building a touchscreen-controlled GUI on a Raspberry Pi for compatibility testing of WiFi routers.  I am cureently working on Python software to automate testing the latest Cync products with voice agents like Alexa and Google Home!   

IBEW Local 38

Journeyman Electrician / Foreman

As an IBEW Journeyman, I learned the importance of the acronym ASK:

Attitude - is everything.  The attitude to get the job done by overcoming obstacles and adapting to changes quickly became ingrained into my daily work habits, allowing for continued success in every project.

Skill - Many of my peers consider me to be an excellent electrician.  I owe my skillset to all of the IBEW journeymen who were patient and generous with their time and talents.

Knowledge - The 5-year apprenticeship provided me with the knowledge to ply my trade.  There is no better way to learn a skill or trade than through an apprenticeship.  As an apprentice, I studied 8 hours every 2 weeks and applied that knowledge while working with other journeymen.

Most of my experience is in the commercial sector, working at various businesses in northeast Ohio (including GE NELA Park) doing large-scale construction projects.  In the industrial sector, I have worked at the Arcelor/Mittal steel mill and Ashland Chemical doing PLC and Class I, Divisions I and II work.
